cover_letter.intro_para: I am very interested applying for the Foundry Operations Co-op at Ginkgo BioWorks. Last year, I had spoken with representatives of the company at a Northeastern University Biotechnology career event, and had proceeded through to a phone interview with a member of the company thereafter, but was deferred due to lack of experience at the time (as it would have been my first co-op). I am still extremely interested in the type of work that Ginkgo is doing, and the doors it will unlock for further biotechnological innovation, and I believe that an opportunity to work at Ginkgo in Spring 2017 would allow for me to both make a noticeable contribution to the team and work being done, as well as provide a unique and powerful learning and skill-development experience as I strive to further develop my competency in this field.

para_background.experience: Through my Bioengineering coursework, with a concentration in Cell and Tissue Engineering, I have gained an understanding of genetics, tissue mechanics, proteomics, and cellular engineering, and continue to pursue opportunities to learn more about the science and find creative ways to apply this knowledge.
para_background.note: For this school experience sentence you can split it up into two sentences just because there needs to be a break so that it does not feel cluttered to the reader. I would suggest breaking it after cellular engineering.
para_background.experience: While on campus, I have volunteered my time in two research labs, developing and executing mechanical engineering experiments in the Bubble Imaging Lab and learning cell culture/passaging, transfection, and biological assay techniques in the Addiction Sciences Lab, which I continue to be involved with. When not doing research, I serve as a mentor with multiple organizations on campus, further developing strong interpersonal and leadership skills that enable my ability to lead groups and harness initiative.

At my first co-op, I gained experience in a neurobiological research setting at Duke Universtiy, gaining proficiency with MatLab and familiarity with python to develop an automated animal behavior training paradigm and conduct comprehensive analysis of both behavioral and calcium imaging experiments. Throughout this experience, I gained skill and experience with both digesting and writing technical documentation, as well as developed ways to abstract simple meaning and explanation of technical concepts. At the end of my co-op, I gave an hour-long comprehensive presentation of my work with both animal behavior and calcium imaging to the entire lab in a lab meeting.

closing_statements.compatability: I believe that my relevant experience, extreme interest in the work being done/potential applications of the technological paradigm being developed at Ginkgo, and personal qualities would make this a great fit.
closing_statements.note: I feel that you could give an addition sentence or two if it be in your closing statements or experience section, where you can give some background on how your skills and experiences translate well to position that you are applying to.
closing_statements.next_step: I eagerly await your call at 1-800-666-5555 so that we can discuss possible next steps and answer questions about moving forward.

docReview.writers_memo: I am mostly finished with the bulk of the process, just looking for any tips or advice regarding content or format. The situation here is my application to a Boston-based biotech company, and presented is my cover letter to be sent with a resume to garner an interview with the company. The simple structure of the genre has been easy to work with, and everything is by and large well-defined, making the template easy to follow. The only difficulty has been the tagging of body content, as some situations are not clearly "work," "personal," or "school," but I suppose in reality it's up to the writer's discretion to decide which tag fits best, and overall it's relatively inconsequential. I would mainly like focus to be on the order of the paragraphs/content presented (I have moved the order around a few times), as well as if any of the information seems extraneous of not directly relevant. For reference: The position is working at a biotech company that uses genetic engineering to take natural principles and engineer novel chemicals/substances such as flavors and scents (right now) for commercial use, using principles of bioengineering and scaling to commercialize discoveries made in the lab. It is a small-ish spinoff from MIT consisting mostly of engineers. Last year when I was phone interviewed, it was with an engineering/recruitment staff, not an HR-background person. I assume an engineering-background individual will likely do the hiring again this year.

report.p: For Ben's project he is writing a cover letter to Ginkgo BioWorks in hopes of landing a Foundry Operations Co-op position. Throughout the cover letter he discusses his background in school, work and personal life, where he brings up many of his skills and accomplishments that he has gained and why he would be a strong choice for the position. I can tell from reading your letter that you have an understanding of the rhetorical situation and audience that you are targeting. Which means that you know that you are apply for a position in which you hope to get an interview and your audience is someone within an engineering/recruitment staff. What really impressed me in your draft was the seamless transition from element to element. What I think could be improved in your letter is your argument as to why you would be the best candidate for the position. I found that you were able to state all of your skills, experiences, and accomplishments well, but you did not engage as much into the actual position and how/why you would fit in there. I would say that the way that you have structured your background paragraphs seem to be good. It looks like you made it a point to transition from your academic experience to your work experience using your personal experience as a mechanism to get from one to the other which I appreciated. I did not find any of information that you included to be extraneous and I found that by including all of these achievements and going into detail with them that you gave off a stronger image of yourself to the employers. Overall I think that your draft was very well constructed and that there are only a few adjustments that should make to improve it.
